titleStmt.title: A true and perfect relation of the happy successe & victory obtained against the Turks of Argiers at Bugia, by His Majesties Fleet in the Mediterranean, under the command of Sr. Edw. Spragge as it is contained in a letter from the said Admiral, of the 11th of May, 1671 : together with an exact list of the Turks ships, burnt and destroyed, with the names of their commanders : as also, one other containing the names of such as were slain or wounded on the part of the English in this memorable action.
titleStmt.author: Spragge, Edward, Sir, d. 1673.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A True and Perfect RELATION OF THE Happy SUCCESSE & VICTORY Obtained again≈øt the Turks of Argiers AT BUGIA, By His MAJESTIES Fleet in the Mediterranean, under the Command OF Sr EDW. SPRAGGE. As it is contained in a Letter from the ≈øaid Admiral, of the Eleventh of May. 1671.

Together with an Exact LIST of the Turks Ships, Burnt and De≈øtroyed, with the Names of their Commanders: As al≈øo, one other containing the Names of ≈øuch as were Slain or Wounded on the Part of the Engli≈øh in this Memorable Action.
In the SAVOY: Printed by Tho. Newcomb. 1671.

div.head: A True and Perfect Relation of the happy Succe≈øs and Victory obtained again≈øt the Turks of Argiers at Bugia, by His Maje≈øties Fleet in the Mediterranean, under the command of Sir Edward Spragge.
div.p: HAving been Crui≈øing for ≈øeveral days before Argiers, the Twentieth of April, being off at Sea, ≈øome Five or ≈øix Leagues, I met with the Mary, Hamp≈øhire, Port≈ømouth, and Advice Fregats; and upon the notice they brought me of ≈øeveral Argiers Men of War being at Bugia, I called a Council of War, and it was voted, and thought fit, That I ≈øhould make the be≈øt of my way (the Wind being then Ea≈øterly) to ply up thither with the Mary, Warwick, Advice, Garland, Port≈ømouth Pink, and the Fire≈øhips, to endeavor the de≈øtroying them; the Hamp≈øhire and Port≈ømouth Fregats being left to crui≈øe off of Argiers till further order. The Dragon had been gone five days in chace of Two Argier Men of War, the Winds being then at S. W. it was ≈øuppo≈øed the Chace had carried him to the Ea≈øtward, and might at la≈øt be forced into Bugia, if not better Fortune, his being ≈øo long ab≈øent, and his well Sailing giving me the greater hopes.

The Twenty third, the Dragon came into me, having been two days in fight with the Two Argier Men of War which he cha≈øed, Capt. Herbert the Commander, being ≈øhot in the Face with a Musket ≈øhot, and Nine or ten of his men wounded with ≈ømall ≈øhot, who will all recover.

Until the Twenty eighth, the Winds were always Ea≈øterly, the ≈øame day, about Eight at Night, the Wind came up to the South We≈øt, with very great Gu≈øts and Rain, which di≈øabled my Little Eagle Fire≈øhip, leaving her not one Ma≈øt ≈øtanding.

The Thirtieth, I had got her Ma≈øted and Rigged again fit for ≈øervice, having luckily a Corn Boat with me taken from the Enemy, which with the help of other Topma≈øts and Booms, Ma≈øted her. In this Weather, the Warwick hapned to ≈øpring her Main Ma≈øt again, and bore away to the Chri≈øtian ≈øhore; my Brigantine at the ≈øame time bore away, and as yet I have no news of her. The ≈øame day I got into Bugia Bay, and had a gale, which I thought would have carried me and my Fire≈øhips in upon them; but by that time we got within half ≈øhot of their Ca≈øtles and Forts, it proved dead calm, and afterward the Wind came off the ≈øhore, and a little further in the Road quite contrary.

The Second of May, the Winds being ≈øo very uncertain, after having twice attempted with my Ships, and not able to do ≈øervice, for want of a certain Wind, every half hour bringing a ≈øeveral Wind with it, I re≈øolved to make an Attempt upon them in the night with my Boats, and the ≈ømalle≈øt of my Fire≈øhips which rowed as well as a Long-Boat: About Twelve a Clock at Night, I ≈øent out all the Boats I could make, and the Eagle Fire≈øhip, under the command of my Elde≈øt Lieutenant Ma≈øter Nugent; but the Night proving very dark, and the high Land ob≈øcuring the Ships as they neer'd them, they pa≈ø≈øed by the Ships (Lieutenant
Nugent leaving one of the Boats with the Fire≈øhip, be≈øides her own) and rowed in to di≈øcover the Enemy, giving the Captain of the Fire≈øhip orders, in ca≈øe he found ≈øhoal Water, to come to an Anchor: He was not a minute from him, when he found him≈øelf within half Pi≈øtol ≈øhot of the Ships; upon which, he ≈øteered off again to find the Fire≈øhip, which to his great a≈øtoni≈øhment was all in a flame. The Enemy then taking the Alarm, it was not convenient for the Boats to attempt boarding and burning them, they being full of Men. Had not this misfortune of the Fire≈øhip hapned, they might at this time have been de≈øtroyed without the lo≈øs of a Man. The next day they unrigged all their Ships, and made a Boom with their Yards, Topma≈øts, and Cables, buoyed up with Cask; in all which time we had no opportunity of Wind to do any thing upon them. My other little Fire≈øhip being ready primed, by an accident of a Pi≈øtol fired by the Gunner, took fire, and was lo≈øt; all my hopes and dependency relying upon her to do this bu≈øine≈øs, in regard of her little draught of Water. Now having nothing to tru≈øt to, but the Little Victory, I pre≈øently gave order to have her lightned to as ≈ømall a draught of water as could be, and brought her to eight foot.

On Munday Morning, being the Eighth of May, came to them ≈øeveral Recruits, both of Hor≈øe and Foot, with Ammunition, as we ≈øuppo≈øe, from Argier, which they welcomed with great triumph by their firing of Guns from the Ships and Ca≈øtles, and putting abroad their Colours. But not knowing what other Recruits might come, I took the fir≈øt opportunity, and about Noon, the ≈øame day, it plea≈øed God to favor us with a fair moderate Breeze at Ea≈øt, though after I had made the ≈øigns for my Men of War to draw into a Line, and fall on, the Wind dollour'd again, which made me de≈øpair of being able to attack them: But it plea≈øed God to order it ≈øo, that
about Two a Clock, the Gale came in as before; the Dragon, Advice, and Mary, borrowed too much of the South-We≈øt ≈øhore; ≈øo that they were forced to let go their Anchors in Three Fathom and half Water, and ≈øo veered in, bringing their Ships broad ≈øide to pa≈øs: I my ≈øelf came to an Anchor in Four Fathom, clo≈øe under their Ca≈øtles and Walls, battering all of us upon their Ships and Ca≈øtles for the ≈øpace of Two hours. I ≈øent in my Pinnace, the Maries and Dragons, to cut the Boom, which was very bravely performed, Lieutenant Pin commanding the Maries Boat, Lieut. Pierce the Dragons, and one Harman (a Reformado Seaman of mine) my own Pinnace; my Second Lieutenant, Mr. Earnly being hurt with a ≈øplinter in the Leg, and could not go; Eight of the Maries Boats Crew, and the Lieutenant were wounded with ≈ømall ≈øhot; Ten of the Dragons, and the Lieutenant wounded, and One killed; Seven killed out right in my own Pinnace, and all the re≈øt wounded except Harman that commanded. The Boom being then cut, I made the ≈øign for my Fire≈øhip to fall on: It plea≈øed Almighty God to order it ≈øo, That ≈øhe got in, and brought up athwart of their Bolt-≈øprits, their Ships being aground, and fa≈øt to the Ca≈øtles, burnt very well, and de≈øtroyed them all, there being in number Ten Sail; Seven of which, were the be≈øt Men of War belonging to Argiers. Capt. Harris, Commander of the Fire≈øhip, his Ma≈øters Mate, Gunner, and one of his Seamen, are de≈øperately wounded with ≈ømall ≈øhot; but I fore≈øeeing the de≈øperatene≈øs and danger of the ≈øervice that was to be done, Commi≈ø≈øionated a ≈øecond Commander Henry Williams, one of my Ma≈øters Mates, and late Commander of the Ro≈øe Fire≈øhip, to take the charge upon him there on Board, in ca≈øe the other ≈øhould mi≈øcarry, which he did accordingly, and performed it very well. The three other which we burnt, be≈øides the Men of War, prove to be a Genoue≈øe a ≈ømall Engli≈øhman, and Satea.

Upon the Tenth, about Eleven a Clock at Night, a Dutchman who hath been a Slave in Argiers for three years (and now with his Patron who commanded one of the≈øe Ships) made his e≈øcape by ≈øwimming on Board me, and told me for certain, That they confe≈øs 360 of their be≈øt Men and upwards, all Turks, Soldiers in Pay, lo≈øt their lives on Board the re≈øpective Ships, by Fire and Gun-≈øhot, not being able to get a≈øhore. But, he ≈øaith, he believes a great many more; for that their Ships were all extraordinary well manned, to the number of about 18 or 1900 Men, be≈øides 300 that arrived there that Morning from Argier, who had been (in our view) received in great triumph; The Ca≈øtles and Town mi≈øerably torn, with an infinite number of the Inhabitants killed and wounded; and that which hapned very luckily to ≈øecond this Succe≈øs, was, That all their Chirurgeons Che≈øts were burnt on Board their Ships, that they have not the lea≈øt Medicine to dre≈øs a Wound with.

Old Treky, their Admiral, is likewi≈øe wounded, who came with the be≈øt and chiefe≈øt Commanders in Argier, to order things in the be≈øt method they could for ≈øecuring their Ships, mo≈øt of which are ≈ølain and wounded.

He al≈øo declares, That the≈øe Ships were purpo≈øely commanded out by the Duan to find me out, and fight me, where ever they met me; and to that end, all the be≈øt Guns in tho≈øe Ships remaining in the Mole, were taken out and mounted in the≈øe; but Eight of which, in each of the≈øe Ships, were put a≈øhore to lighten them the better, the re≈øt are all burnt and ≈øpoiled.

div.head: An Exact Li≈øt of the Argier Ships burnt in Bugia, with their Number of Guns and Age. May 8. 1671.

row.cell: Burnt near Tadellis, a Man of War

div.p: Turks Captains Slain, Mehammet Segara, Mantuccero alias Buttercoper, Dan≈øiker Renegado, Braham Rais, Courhali his Renegado (a Genoe≈øe) and next Captain under him.
The≈øe are all I have yet an account of, though we are a≈ø≈øured there are many more.

div.head: A Li≈øt of the Men Killed and Wounded in the Ships following at Bugia. May 8. 1671.
